reference.shortdesc: The hwcontrol element represents the name of a key, button, switch, or other physical control on a device.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: Implementations that require different output for different types of hardware controls can use the outputclass attribute to distinguish between different types of usage.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The hwcontrol element is specialized from ph. It is defined in the hardware domain module.

example.title: Example
example.p: The following code samples show how hwcontrol can be used within task steps to identify hardware controls, including examples that use outputclass to distiguish between types of controls.
example.codeblock: <step><cmd>If the command is already running, select the command window and press <hwcontrol>CTRL+C</hwcontrol> to end processing.</cmd></step>

<step><cmd>After entering the amount you received, press <hwcontrol>Amt Tend</hwcontrol>.</cmd> <stepresult>This opens the cash drawer. The display shows the amount of change to give the customer.</stepresult></step>

<step><cmd>To set your machine for this type of hem, set the <hwcontrol outputclass="knob">Stitch Length</hwcontrol> to <userinput>3</userinput> and the <hwcontrol outputclass="lever">Stitch Selector</hwcontrol> to <userinput>D</userinput>.

<step><cmd>To sew backwards, set the <hwcontrol outputclass="discrete-control">Stitch Length</hwcontrol> to <userinput>Reverse</userinput> and press the <hwcontrol outputclass="continuous-control">pedal</hwcontrol> with your foot.
